nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: You step into the campus community garden. It’s quiet, alive, and clearly cared for by people who show up consistently.

nodes.speaker: gardener
nodes.text: Hey. We’re maintaining this space so it actually stays useful for students. Helping out or just looking around?

choices.text: I want to help. I’ve been trying to be more involved lately.
I’ll observe for now. I’m still figuring things out.

nodes.speaker: gardener
nodes.text: That mindset matters more than people think. Consistency beats big talk.

nodes.speaker: gardener
nodes.text: Fair. Awareness comes before action anyway.

nodes.speaker: system
nodes.text: You spend some time in the garden, reflecting on what real involvement looks like.

nodes.speaker: narrator
nodes.text: Later that day, you meet your professor after class. He notices you hesitate before speaking, as if you’re weighing your thoughts carefully.

nodes.speaker: professor
nodes.text: You’ve been quite involved lately. Tell me—what do you think all of this has actually taught you?

choices.text: That small, consistent actions matter more than just understanding the theory.
That sustainability is more complex than I realised.

nodes.speaker: professor
nodes.text: That’s an important realisation. Awareness without action doesn’t change anything. What matters is what you choose to do when it’s uncomfortable or inconvenient.

nodes.speaker: professor
nodes.text: Understanding the complexity is only the beginning. The harder part is deciding where you’re willing to take responsibility.

nodes.speaker: professor
nodes.text: Look closely at everyday life—how people handle waste, water, food, transport. Change doesn’t start with big gestures, but with choices people make daily.

nodes.speaker: system
nodes.text: You leave the classroom with a clearer sense of direction.
